The third main text, ten kinds of power-holding, has thirty chapters, answering the previous ten practices and thirty questions.
Ancient masters divide it into three parts:
The first six chapters clarify the practice of vast and far-reaching great aspirations;
The second, from ten kinds of inconceivability and below, nine chapters, clarify the practice of the function of samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä;
The third, from ten kinds of garden groves and below, fifteen chapters, clarify the practice of perfect completion of virtues.
However, in terms of perfect interfusion, this meaning is not without.
Now, without destroying the sequence, it also manifests the practices within the ten practices.

The first practice has three chapters, the second and third practices each have one, the fourth practice has two chapters, the fifth practice has six chapters, the next four practices each have two chapters, and the tenth practice has nine chapters. This will be known in the text.

The reason for the number of approaches used is that giving is at the beginning, so it has three, precepts and patience are common to the world, so they have only one, and concentration and wisdom are supreme, so they have many approaches.
Since wisdom has many, therefore in prajÃ±Ä it is abbreviated, and the other two are used only for the next two superior [approaches].

Moreover, although these ten practices are based on the ten perfections, the meaning is mostly inclusive, so in the text sometimes the meaning is explained in terms of the ten perfections, and sometimes the names of the practices are used for explanation.
Now, the first three approaches clarify the practices within the practice of joyful giving.
Among the three, the first clarifies the power of upholding.

This includes general and specific meanings. Generally, since this is the head of the ten practices, it is based on these ten things to empower and establish them, and one can initiate various practices. Therefore, the Sutra of Crossing Over the World calls them the ten establishments.

Specifically, in the practice of joyful giving, all acts of giving are for the cultivation and practice of the Buddhas' original practices, etc., and therefore it is the intention to establish the practice.
Among the ten, the first three of the Three Jewels are the upholding of the realm.
Sentient beings are the Sangha Jewel because the Sangha of Bodhisattvas is the world of sentient beings;

The remaining seven are practices of compassion, because they are the correct practices, because they uphold the practices through vows, and because the practices with the realm of compassion and wisdom are accomplished.
Time is the time when the practices arise.
The last two are merit and wisdom.
However, in the section on the end of the tenth ground, there are eleven practices, with the fourth adding the practice of afflictions.
In the discussion of practices, the first two are counterintuitive practices, which are based on the fact that they do not cut off manifestations;
Here they are only based on being the basis for practice, so there are no afflictions.
There is the practice of making offerings and the practice of eons, but there is no practice of realms and no practice of good powers;
Here time includes eons, and the practice includes good powers based on realms giving rise to offerings, so they are both not different.
The other names are the same, as explained there.
Since the names are different, they are explained according to the names. This does not contradict the general principle of having the teaching but not yet having the Sangha treasure.

Above, it distinguishes dhÄraá¹‡Ä« as the retention of the text and meaning, next it says receiving and upholding is receiving and practicing, now it says power upholding is empowering and upholding, therefore they are not confused. Below this is the fifty-fourth chapter.
The second great joy and comfort correctly explains the meaning of the practice of joy.
They only see beggars coming and are doubly joyful;
Now, knowing that it is because of giving that they see the Buddha, make offerings to the Buddha, etc., the mind greatly rejoices, the initial practice is mostly the same as the ground of joy.
The ten are briefly divided into five pairs:

1. The pair of serving the Buddha and making offerings to the Buddha, 2. The pair of listening to the Dharma and associating with the good, 3. The pair of accomplishing the practices of benefiting oneself and others, 4. The pair of adorning the land and transforming beings, 5. The pair of being able to see what is difficult to see and being able to accomplish what is difficult to accomplish. The textual appearances are very clear.
Third, the ten kinds of profound penetration. Above it clarifies the joy in advance of future accomplishment;
This clarifies the present ability to realize and understand, which is the practice of the Dharma giving mentioned above.
They say, I will study all that the Buddhas have studied, realize omniscience, know all dharmas, and teach sentient beings.
Among the ten, the first six have the word enter, while the latter four take knowing as the initial [step]. The two phrases realize and enter and know and understand are clearly distinguished.
Among them, the first four enter the vessel world. The first three specifically enter the three times, while the last one generally clarifies [the vessel world].

Among the specific [entries], the present internal counting refers to the number of dharmas, the activities refer to the causes of lands, the explanations refer to the teachings within each and every fruit, and the purity refers to the essence of lands. This is the common essence.
The last general phrase says various natures, which refers to the distinctions of defilement and purity, and so on. This is the specific essence.
The next two enter the sentient beings' world.
The last four enter the world of wisdom and right enlightenment.
Among them, the first three enter the Buddhas of the three times, while the last one enters the Dharma.
Among the Dharma, the first is knowing the distinctions of the five vehicles;

Later, below although knowing, it clarifies the dual practice of provisional and real, because the nature does not destroy the characteristics, although there is no discrimination, it speaks of various kinds.
Here, discrimination is precisely differentiation, so the Jin edition of the sÅ«tra says, Although all dharmas are neither one nor different, it speaks of one and different.

Next, it says, all enter the dharma realm because there is nowhere to enter, explaining the above meaning, that is, because all enter the dharma realm there is no differentiation, and because there is nowhere to enter it speaks of various kinds.
What is that?
If there were a separate place to enter, then when entering the original characteristics would be lost, and various kinds could not be spoken of.
Because the dharma itself is empty, it is called entering the dharma realm, with nothing else to enter, then the various kinds are not destroyed.
Speaking as it is and below, the above distinguishes knowing, and below this it clarifies speaking.
The one who speaks the Dharma should speak the Dharma as it is. Since the Dharma is the dual fusion of provisional and real, speaking is also precisely speaking without attachment.
Second, the ten kinds of reliance clarify the practices within the stage of benefiting others.
Above it clarifies realization and entry, now it relies on good conditions.
Universally relying on these ten directions, one is able to benefit others, not just relying on precepts, let alone precepts having the inclusion of goodness, what is not complete?
Third, the ten kinds of fearlessness are the practices within the stage of being without opposition.
Due to relying on the bodhisattva's wholesome cessation, one is able to do what is difficult to do, able to endure what is difficult to endure, and gives rise to a fearless mind.

One, difficult to extinguish obstacles; two, difficult to protect the bequeathed Dharma; three, difficult to subdue evil mÄras; four, difficult to abandon body and life; five, difficult to subdue non-Buddhists; six, difficult to satisfy the minds of beings; seven, difficult to delight the great assembly; eight, difficult to tame the eight groups of beings; nine, difficult to leave the lower vehicles; ten, difficult to cultivate the higher practices.
Within these ten difficulties, one is without fear, how could one fear beings harming each other?
Fourth, the two sections below giving rise to an unwavering mind clarify the practices within the stage of being without bending.
Among them, this gate is due to being fearless in the face of difficulties, thus resolutely and without doubt in the ten deeds, which is the practice within the armor-like vigor;
The latter gate encompasses the practice of accumulating goodness, and benefiting and delighting pervades both gates.

Now, the first ten include: 1. Embracing sentient beings with the ten perfections, 2. Serving and making offerings to Buddhas, 3. Radiating light and adorning Buddha-lands, 4. Taming and maturing for a long time, 5. Endowed with omniscience, 6. Acting as a bright lamp for the world, 7. Expounding the Dharma to awaken, 8. Destroying hindrances and attaining Buddhahood, 9. Separating from delusion and self-realization, 10. Resolutely attaining enlightenment.
Making vows and commitments regarding these ten matters is called armor-like.
Second, the ten kinds of inconceivability are the goodness that is embraced. Because of resolute and unquestioning resolve, what is done is difficult to fathom.
Among the ten, the first three are solely about wholesome roots. Vows and wisdom in accordance with the nature are called inconceivable.

The remaining seven are both expedient and real, and therefore inconceivable. Among them, the first four are about practice, and the latter three are about wisdom. Wisdom is about internal clarity, and practice is about external characteristics.

Among the former, the first four are about engaging with existence while the one path is pure, the fifth is about realizing emptiness while myriad practices boil over, the sixth is about cultivating causes and completing the fruition of the eight appearances, and the seventh is about manifesting fruition while not abandoning great function. All of these are difficult to conceive.

Among the latter three, the eighth is about the two truths mutually including each other, the ninth is about the three matters merging yet not merging, and the tenth is about expedient and real mutually including yet not including each other.
In the eighth, there are ten sentences in five pairs:
The first is about objects, the second is about mind, the third is about all, the fourth is about cultivation and arising, and the fifth is about names.
This is also the five dharmas:
The first is characteristics, the second is delusion, the third is suchness, the fourth is right wisdom, and the fifth is names.
However, each has two meanings:
The first is directly about the essence of the dharma. No characteristics is the true, and characteristics is the conventional. They always mutually include each other. The other four are the same.

Second, in terms of delusion and enlightenment, there are five pairs that are mostly the same but slightly different, namely: 1. Delusion is the non-appearance of suchness becoming appearance, and enlightenment is the appearance of suchness being suchness itself;
2. Delusion is the nondiscrimination of right cognition becoming deluded discrimination, and enlightenment is deluded discrimination being right cognition without discrimination;
3. Understanding suchness as not existent is true suchness, but if one grasps at suchness as existent, it is not true suchness;
4. If cognition is non-action, it is right cognition, but if there is something to be done, it is not right cognition;
5. Knowing that names are not speech is true speech, that is, names have speech but are not speech.
Among the nine, the first is the fusion of the three matters, and the latter also not reveals the characteristics of detachment and fusion, which is called non-fusion.
The three matters are mind, Buddha, and sentient beings, all of which are without distinction, like the verses of Jue Lin.
Among the ten, there are three sentences. The first clarifies the exhaustion that is not exhausted. This is about the time of severing to clarify the essence and function;
Second, non-existence but not non-existence, this will use the nature of dharmas against cessation to clarify essence and function.
Although the two phrases are different, they are both the dual practice of skillful means and truth.
Third, although knowing the Buddha Dharma below clarifies the immediate and the non-immediate.
Within this, first it clarifies, and later all dharmas below explains the above meaning.

All enter the Dharma realm, therefore the characteristics are said to be immediate. There is nowhere to enter, therefore one should not discriminate the Buddha Dharma and so forth within the world. It is said that because the future Dharma is empty by itself, it is called the characteristics are immediate. The Buddha Dharma within the world cannot be obtained.
The following re-explains:
Because it is known that all dharmas are non-dual, one cannot seek each other within the two.
Because there is no change, the worldly dharmas also do not make those Buddha Dharmas.
Think about it.
Fifth, below the ten kinds of skillful secret words, the following six chapters clarify the practice within the absence of delusion and confusion.
Within this, there are three:
The first two gates are the practices of non-delusion, the next two gates clarify the practices of non-disorder, and the last two gates both clarify the two gates that give rise to merits.
Although delusion and disorder are general, now they are explained from the specific.

Moreover, these three sections are the three dhyÄnas: the first is the dhyÄna of benefiting sentient beings, the second is the dhyÄna of abiding in the bliss of the true Dharma, and the third is the dhyÄna of giving rise to merits.
Now, in the first two gates, the first gate does not foolishly misunderstand the skillful and secret words, and the latter gate does not foolishly misunderstand the skillful wisdom.
Now, the first.
Since the previous clarifies internal practices, now it discusses external words.

The text on those practices says, By means of right mindfulness, one skillfully understands all the worldly verbal expressions, and is able to uphold the verbal expressions of the supramundane dharmas, and so forth.
All secret words generally clarify five:
First, because it expounds the profound secret Dharma, such as the Chapter on Appearance which is called the Secret Treasury of the TathÄgata and so forth.
Second, because it explains all dharmas in one word, as stated above, The TathÄgata in one word... and so forth, it is also like the four meanings and nine meanings of the word Gautama by the sage.
Third, not hearing what is near, like ÅšÄriputra being on the seat but not hearing, or like MaudgalyÄyana seeking sound from afar.
Fourth, speaking near but meaning far, like saying the three vehicles are the ultimate and so forth;
speaking far but meaning near, like saying obtaining fire when cold is called nirvÄá¹‡a and so forth, this meaning is also called concealing the real and speaking of the provisional.
Fifth, using different words to speak of different dharmas, like realizing the unfirm as firm and so forth.
There are ten phrases in the text:
The first one has five meanings, because it is the general and all teachings;
The next two contain two meanings, referring to revealing but considering it real, which is the fourth meaning;
These two are both profound and secret dharmas, which is the first meaning;
The rest are common to the first two, or all five are included, which can be understood.
Second, the ten kinds of skillful discrimination wisdom.
Because the external words are secret and the internal wisdom is skillful, there is no delusion in benefiting sentient beings.
That text says, The bodhisattva listens to the correct Dharma from a good and wise advisor, namely the profound Dharma, and so forth.
The text and meaning are mostly the same as the ten phrases, which can be understood.
The second two aspects clarify the practice without confusion, which are all the essence of concentration.
Among them, the first aspect clarifies entering samÄdhi, showing the differences in place, etc.;
The latter clarifies universal entry, which touches all things universally.
Now, at the beginning, that text says, Skillfully entering all the gates of dhyÄna concentration.
Here, it is clarified that the ten all pervade everything.
Among the ten, generally distinguishing the ten objects, entering concentration is different, and specifically the ten aspects are different.
But the first five are single-layered events;
The remaining five are mutually inclusive and perfectly integrated, which can be understood.

The ninety are all one and yet many, so the practice says in a single thought one attains innumerable samÄdhis. It is only from the majority that it is explained and distinguished as the essence of samÄdhi in relation to what precedes and follows, it is not that it is useless.
Second, the ten universal entrances are also like the small vehicle's teaching of the ten universal bases, which cause the samÄdhis to gradually increase and expand.
Previously it was explained that all is like the bodies of sentient beings, referring to the bodies of youths and so forth. Although one can enter all bodies, it is not necessarily all at once;
Now this is following entry into one category, all pervading everything, like when Haihui first came, all at once it was water and so forth.
The ten phrases can be understood.
Third, the two gates below the ten liberations clarify the meditation of generating meritorious qualities. This gate clarifies the unobstructed function, therefore it is called liberation;
The later gate has nothing obstructing it in regard to objects, therefore it is called spiritual powers.
Now, at the beginning, liberation is also the conceivable liberation.
The Sanskrit is vimukti, meaning supreme liberation, referring to the superior function of accomplishing the eight liberations without relying on dhyÄna.
The ten phrases can be understood.
Second, the ten kinds of spiritual powers are like the six common spiritual powers based on the four dhyÄnas.
If these ten are classified into the previous four, they are as follows.
The next five are spiritual powers.
The last one is the extinction of contamination, because it accomplishes enlightenment.
Based on different stages, it is slightly different from the ten spiritual powers.
The sixth, the two chapters below ten kinds of illumination, clarify the practices in the stage of skillful means.
This chapter directly reveals the essence of practice, which is prajÃ±Ä, and is therefore called illumination of wisdom;
The following chapter clarifies the liberation from the obstacle of wisdom, and is therefore called liberation.

Now, they are all the wisdom of unobstructed skillful means, and are therefore called skillful means. They are not like the ten perfections, which are only based on the fundamental [wisdom], but are divided into five practices based on the differences in their increase and decrease.
Among the ten, the first seven are based on a single wisdom, while the last three are practiced in pairs.
In the first part, the first three are about what is to be transformed;
the next three are about the ability to transform, each first about phenomena, next about principle, and finally returning phenomena to principle;
the seventh is about leaving behind the thoughts of subject and object and returning to prajÃ±Ä.
Thinking, imagining, and views are eliminated, and one does not grasp at objects, in order to skillfully enter into principle.

In the last three about practicing both, the eighth clarifies the skillful wisdom of teaching without teaching and accomplishing without accomplishing. This means illuminating quiescence by means of the non-dual, and being able to make distinctions while transcending words.

Illuminating phenomena, there is teaching; non-characteristics eliminate characteristics, non-non-existence eliminates existence; one nature eliminates multiplicity, non-nature eliminates existence; the nature and characteristics are both quiescent.

Abiding in below refers to accomplishing without accomplishing. The essence of the Dharma realm is truly without anything to accomplish. Illuminating this Dharma realm is precisely called accomplishing Buddhahood.
The ninth clarifies the wisdom of non-arising and arising.
The text has three parts:
first it clarifies correctly, next from why it cites and explains, and third from this is called it concludes the name.
First, clarifying the objectless object, and also revealing the transformation without transformation.
Within this, there are two parts:
First, clarifying the objectless, meaning that the true mind of sentient beings accords with principle and cannot be attained, so if there is no object, then there is no one to be transformed.
And knowing below clarifies the true mind following conditions, not destroying conditioned arising, and thus also having someone to be transformed.
Within this, there are two parts:
First, knowing those to be transformed, and later, concluding the two practices.
The text in the first part has three sections:

First, there are eight sentences separately knowing the characteristics of conditions. Causes refer to ignorance, etc., conditions refer to karmic activity, events refer to consciousness, name-and-form, etc., objects refer to contact, sensation, and objective realms, practice refers to present craving, grasping, and becoming, birth refers to the stage of birth, and cessation refers to old age and death.
Knowing speech means all of this accords with convention, because conditioned arising is not apart from the three periods of time.
Second, knowing delusion below has twelve sentences in six pairs, which clarifies knowing defilement, purity, delusion, and enlightenment.

If one is deluded about principle, then one is confused, defiled, and inverted; if one awakens, then one is the opposite of this. If one follows convention, then both are obtainable; in the ultimate truth, both are unobtainable. Obtainable and unobtainable are based on principle; attachment and non-attachment are based on wisdom.
Third, knowing abiding and below clarifies knowing the activity of the mind.
Abiding refers to the original nature; movement refers to guest dust.
Following guest dust is to go without returning; seeing the original nature is to return to the source and revert to the origin.
Having and returning, going and coming, are all arising of the mind. Returning to abide, both are absent, tranquil, and do not arise.
If one arises, then all wholesome dharmas are lost; if one does not arise, then one leaves the covers and entanglements, and touches the realm with tranquil knowledge. This is called maturity.
Above, it is common to both self and others; below, it is also knowing the capacities.
In terms of one's own faculties, it means the six faculties are not dragged by objects, which is precisely taming.
Later, following and below concludes the two practices, meaning that wisdom follows curved transformation, without losing non-action.
Second, in the questioning and explanation, the reason for this is because one gives rise to the mind for the sake of beings.
The name is easy to understand.
The tenth is the wisdom light of equal teaching and transformation, which has three parts:

First, it clarifies that the real does not obstruct the provisional; second, knowing the various clarifies that the provisional does not obstruct the real; third, in birth and death concludes the name, all of which are easy to understand.
Second, the ten kinds of liberation are because they liberate from the two hindrances.
The Sanskrit word vimukti means liberation, which is different from the previous [ten kinds of liberation].
Among the ten, the first four liberate from the three hindrances of ordinary beings because they take increase as their function;
The latter six liberate from the cognitive hindrances.
The first distinguishes the inferior, while the rest all manifest the superior.
The seventh and eighth two gates clarify the practices within the stage of non-attachment.
Among them, this gate clarifies the enjoyment of indulging in pleasures, while the latter gate clarifies the comfort of dwelling.
Both are common to the two benefits, skillful means of the provisional and real, and are without attachment.
The first is easy to understand.
Second, among the ten palaces, the four brahma abodes are the four immeasurables, which are also the causes of form.
Therefore, the Sutra on Transcending the World says, Cultivate the four immeasurables of kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity.
The rest can be understood.
The eighth two gates below what is enjoyed clarify the practices in the difficult to attain stage.
Among them, this gate is the internal mind's aspiration and enjoyment. Aspiration is the essence of practice. Since one is in the palace, one's feelings delight in supreme enjoyment.
The twenty adornments are the external virtues and adornments, because one adorns aspiration with many virtues.
The text can all be understood.
The ninth two gates below unwavering mind clarify the practices in the good dharmas stage.
This gate clarifies the unmoving by external conditions, while the later gate clarifies the non-abandonment of the internal mind.
Moreover, this clarifies the firmness of the mind, while the later clarifies the deep penetration, both of which are the meaning of power.
Now, the first ten, the second and ninth are the power of investigation, while the rest are all the power of cultivation.
The eighth has ten:
First, faith, because one gives rise to the Buddha's fruition;
Second, unmixed, because of the impurity of disbelief;
Third, pure, because free from afflictions;
Fourth, because free from subtle thoughts;
Fifth, because free from the defilements of knowables;
Sixth, because penetrating to the source of phenomena;
Seventh, because heading towards the fruition stage;
Eighth, because one's own virtues are firm;
Ninth, because one's virtues are inexhaustible;
Tenth, because one's causes are unshakable;
Eleventh, because one realizes suchness.
The rest are all self-evident.

Second, the mind of profundity and greatness is not abandoned, because by being unshakable one is able to exhaust principle and phenomena. Principle is profound and phenomena are vast, hence profundity and greatness.
The ten phrases can be understood.
In the ninth section below wisdom observation, the ten chapters clarify the practices within the stage of reality.
It is divided into nine parts:

1. Observational wisdom, 2. wisdom of expounding the Dharma, 3. wisdom of freedom from hindrances, 4. wisdom of thorough decision, 5. wisdom of penetrating illumination, 6. wisdom of being unequaled, 7. wisdom of being without inferiority, 8. wisdom of being lofty and outstanding, 9. wisdom of profundity and vastness.
First, because one does not abandon profundity and greatness, one is able to observe.
The previous question only mentioned observation, omitting the word wisdom. The ten phrases can be understood by analogy.
Second, the wisdom of expounding the Dharma. Because one is able to contemplate internally, one is able to expound externally.
Among the ten, the first two expound the conventional, and the latter eight expound the true.

One, there is no duality that can be disputed; two, the essence and virtues are both vast; three, the characteristics are profound and far-reaching; four, the essence is firm and sharp; five, suchness is unmoving; six, the essence transcends the hundred negations; seven, being in the entanglements is not defiled; eight, the essence and characteristics are of one flavor.
Third, the ten kinds of purity are the wisdom of freedom from hindrances.
This freedom from the wisdom hindrances is called stainless in the Jin edition.
Although they are the same in purity, what is purified is not the same.
Among the ten, there are differences in the opening and closing of the seven purities, which are easily understood in the text.
The seven purities are explained at the beginning of the fifth ground.
Fourth, the ten kinds of seals are the wisdom of certainty, because the pure wisdom definitely seals and approves all dharmas, so in the Jin edition it is called the wisdom seal.
The benefits that are subsequently gained are also the seal of wisdom, just like the three Dharma seals and so forth.

Among the ten, the first is the wisdom of patience in peacefully accepting suffering, the second is the patience of others not benefiting, the third is the patience of deeply believing in the Buddha's teachings, which is the patience of contemplating the Dharma, the fourth is the determination to attain Buddhahood and deliver sentient beings, the fifth is the determination to know that the Buddha's wisdom is boundless, the sixth is the determination to not regress in seeking the Buddha's fruition, the seventh is the determination to not care for one's body and life in order to be close to the Dharma, the eighth is the determination to deliver those who have entered the Great Vehicle, the ninth is the determination to deliver equally, and the tenth is the determination to be the same as the Buddha in perfecting the causes and fruition.
Fifth, the illumination of wisdom refers to penetrating wisdom. Because of the seal of determination, the illumination is unobstructed. The ten phrases are easy to understand.

Sixth, the unsurpassed abode refers to unsurpassed wisdom. Because of the previous penetration, one does not dwell in biased attachment. Dwelling in both phenomena and principles is called unsurpassed.
Among the ten, all are the dual practice of skillful means and truth, either the function of quiescence or the function of quiescence in activity, etc., all can be clearly understood.
Seventh, the absence of a lowly mind, which is the absence of inferior wisdom.
Above, it is said that there is nothing equal to it from below, and now it is said that there is nothing inferior to it from above.
Because it is determined to accomplish the ten superior matters, it is called the absence of a lowly mind, which is why the Jin edition calls it the absence of timidity.
There are ten phrases in five pairs:

The first is the pair of subduing demons and restraining outsiders, the second is the pair of delighting in others and fulfilling oneself, the third is the pair of accumulating blessings and perfecting wisdom, the fourth is the pair of transforming below and accomplishing above, the first four are discussed individually;
The fifth is the pair of the ultimate of compassion and wisdom, which is the dual practice.
Among them, the first nine are the compassion of wisdom, and the dual practice of compassion and wisdom, although compassionate, do not seek karmic retribution.
The tenth is the skillful means of the wisdom of compassion, and the dual practice of skillful means and truth, which is divided into four parts:
First, listing what is to be known;
Second, thus and below distinguishes the knower, meaning knowing the false awakening of suffering, seeing the principle and realizing cessation, cultivating the path to eliminate accumulation;
Third, however and below brushes away the characteristics of that knowledge. Because the knower is non-discriminating, there are no merits. Because the known is not various, there are no objects.
Fourth, not existent and below unifies and returns to the middle way, extensively distinguishing the two practices.
Among them, the first two sentences generally distinguish the middle way;
Next, with the non-dual and below, the realm and wisdom are contrasted, both clarifying that the real wisdom knows the provisional, manifesting the unobstructed two practices.
Among them, difference is discussed vertically, in terms of transformation;
Distinction is discussed horizontally, in terms of dissimilarity.
Later, with the ultimate Dharma realm and below, the essence gives rise to function to distinguish the two practices.
Eighth, like the mountain superior mind, distinguishing the lofty wisdom.
Because of the absence of inferiority, the myriad practices are outstanding, difficult to look up to their loftiness.
In making superior decisions, one directly proceeds to enlightenment, which cannot be shaken.
Among the ten, the first is diligently cultivating the wisdom that can be realized;
The second is always contemplating the principle that is realized;
The third is cultivating internally without outflows;

The fourth is externally befriending good people, seeking fame and profit, and claiming to have understood after hearing the words of others, which is stealing the Dharma. The Sutra of Contemplating the Buddha's SamÄdhi says that this person will fall into hell as quickly as an arrow is shot. Later students should be warned;
The fifth is that the great forbearance and life-affirming great vows increase even more, like firewood fueling a fire;

The sixth is decisively transcending the realm of mÄras, due to accomplishing superior virtues and not being attached. Only using the joy of the Dharma to sustain oneself, then the realm of mÄras is all the realm of buddhas;
The seventh is diligently and courageously practicing cultivation. The MahÄyÄnasaá¹ƒgraha says, The foolish cultivate for a short time, with lazy minds doubting it takes a long time;
The Buddha, over immeasurable eons, diligently and courageously considers it to be a moment.
The eighth is not abandoning evil people;
The ninth is standing alone and equal to the buddhas;
The tenth is the dual practice of skillful means and truth.
There are four parts in the text:
First, it clarifies the practice of the two together.
Second, from Why is it so? it cites and explains.
There are two intentions in the citation:
First, it says that practice must accord with principle, and since principle is non-attainment, why not abandon the vow?
Since one does not abandon the vow, why practice the contemplation of non-attainment?
There is an obstruction in advancing and retreating.
Second, the explanation also has two intentions:
First, it says that if there is attainment, one cannot attain bodhi, but because of non-attainment, bodhi arises.
Therefore, although one does not abandon the vow, one must contemplate non-attainment.

Second, it says that the dharma of non-attainment is not outside of attainment, and one must seek all dharmas in order to exhaust the source of non-attainment. Therefore, in order to realize non-attainment, one must not abandon the vow of bodhi.
Third, from Therefore it concludes the practice of the two together.
Fourth, from Not doing this it reveals the avoidance of error, because one is not afraid of emptiness and does not seek it.
Ninth, the wisdom like the ocean is the wisdom of profundity and vastness.
